Class HtmlTag

java.lang.Object
io.mindspice.simplypages.core.HtmlTag
All Implemented Interfaces:
Component
Direct Known Subclasses:
AccountWidget, Alert, Audio, Badge, Blockquote, Breadcrumb, Button, Card, Code, Column, Comment, CommentThread, Container, DataTable, Div, Divider, EditablePage, EditableRow, Form, ForumPost, Grid, Header, Icon, Image, InfoBox, Label, Link, ListItem, Modal, Module, NavBar, OrderedList, Page, Paragraph, PostList, ProgressBar, Row, Section, Select, SideNav, Spacer, Spinner, Table, Tag, TextArea, TextInput, UnorderedList, Video
public class HtmlTag extends Object implements Component
Abstract base class for all HTML tag components in the framework.

HtmlTag provides the core functionality for rendering HTML elements with attributes, children, and text content. This class implements the Component interface and serves as the foundation for all concrete HTML components.

Key Features

  • Fluent API: All configuration methods return this for method chaining
  • Attribute Management: Add any HTML attribute via withAttribute(String, String)
  • Component Nesting: Build complex hierarchies with withChild(Component)
  • Text Content: Set simple text content with withInnerText(String)
  • Self-Closing Tags: Support for <img />, <br />, etc.

Component Structure

Every HtmlTag consists of:

  • Tag Name: The HTML element type (div, p, h1, etc.)
  • Attributes: Zero or more HTML attributes (class, id, style, etc.)
  • Inner Text: Optional simple text content
  • Children: Zero or more nested Component instances
  • Self-Closing Flag: Whether the tag is self-closing

Usage Examples

Basic Element

HtmlTag div = new HtmlTag("div")
    .withAttribute("class", "container")
    .withInnerText("Hello World");

div.render();
// Output: <div class="container">Hello World</div>

Nested Structure

HtmlTag container = new HtmlTag("div")
    .withAttribute("class", "container")
    .withChild(new HtmlTag("h1").withInnerText("Title"))
    .withChild(new HtmlTag("p").withInnerText("Content"));

container.render();
// Output: <div class="container"><h1>Title</h1><p>Content</p></div>

Self-Closing Tag

HtmlTag img = new HtmlTag("img", true)
    .withAttribute("src", "/photo.jpg")
    .withAttribute("alt", "Photo");

img.render();
// Output: <img src="/photo.jpg" alt="Photo" />

HTMX Integration

HtmlTag button = new HtmlTag("button")
    .withInnerText("Load More")
    .withAttribute("hx-get", "/api/items")
    .withAttribute("hx-target", "#content")
    .withAttribute("hx-swap", "beforeend");

button.render();
// Output: <button hx-get="/api/items" hx-target="#content" hx-swap="beforeend">Load More</button>

Method Chaining (Fluent API)

HtmlTag card = new HtmlTag("div")
    .withAttribute("class", "card")
    .withAttribute("id", "user-card-123")
    .withChild(new HtmlTag("h2").withInnerText("User Profile"))
    .withChild(new HtmlTag("p").withInnerText("Name: John Doe"))
    .withChild(new HtmlTag("p").withInnerText("Email: john@example.com"));

Subclassing HtmlTag

Most concrete components extend HtmlTag to provide specialized functionality:

public class Button extends HtmlTag {
    public Button() {
        super("button");
    }

    public static Button create(String text) {
        return new Button().withInnerText(text);
    }

    public Button primary() {
        return (Button) this.withAttribute("class", "btn btn-primary");
    }
}

// Usage:
Button btn = Button.create("Click Me").primary();

Rendering Process

The Component.render() method generates HTML in this order:

  1. Opening tag: <tagName
  2. Attributes: class="container" id="main"
  3. Close opening tag: > (or /> for self-closing)
  4. Inner text content (if any)
  5. Rendered children (recursively)
  6. Closing tag: </tagName> (if not self-closing)

Thread Safety

HtmlTag instances are not thread-safe. Each component should be constructed for a single render operation. Do not share component instances across multiple requests.

Performance Considerations

  • Components are rendered on-demand when Component.render() is called
  • No caching is performed - each call to render() generates new HTML
  • For large component trees, consider rendering in chunks or using pagination

  • Constructor Details

    • HtmlTag

      public HtmlTag(String tagName, boolean selfClosing)
      Creates a new HTML tag with the specified name and self-closing flag.
      Parameters:
      tagName - the HTML element name (e.g., "div", "span", "button")
      selfClosing - true for self-closing tags (<img />), false for normal tags (<div></div>)

    • HtmlTag

      public HtmlTag(String tagName)
      Creates a new non-self-closing HTML tag with the specified name.

      This is the most common constructor for standard HTML elements.

      Parameters:
      tagName - the HTML element name (e.g., "div", "span", "button")

  • Method Details

    • withAttribute

      public HtmlTag withAttribute(String name, String value)
      Adds an HTML attribute to this tag.

      Attributes are rendered in the order they are added.

      Common attributes:

      • class - CSS classes for styling
      • id - Unique element identifier
      • style - Inline CSS styles
      • data-* - Custom data attributes
      • hx-* - HTMX attributes for dynamic behavior

      Examples:

      tag.withAttribute("class", "btn btn-primary");
tag.withAttribute("id", "submit-button");
tag.withAttribute("hx-get", "/api/data");
tag.withAttribute("required", "");  // Boolean attribute
      Parameters:
      name - the attribute name (e.g., "class", "id", "href")
      value - the attribute value (use empty string for boolean attributes)
      Returns:
      this HtmlTag instance for method chaining

    • withChild

      public HtmlTag withChild(Component component)
      Adds a child component to this tag.

      Children are rendered in the order they are added, after any inner text.

      Examples:

      div.withChild(new Header.H1("Title"));
div.withChild(new Paragraph().withInnerText("Content"));
div.withChild(Form.create().addField("Name", TextInput.create("name")));
      Parameters:
      component - the child component to add
      Returns:
      this HtmlTag instance for method chaining

    • withInnerText

      public HtmlTag withInnerText(String text)
      Sets the simple text content for this tag.

      Inner text is rendered before any child components. For complex content with formatting, consider using child components instead.

      Security: The text will be automatically HTML-escaped to prevent XSS attacks. Characters like <, >, &, ", and ' will be converted to HTML entities.

      If you need to render trusted HTML (e.g., from a Markdown parser), use withUnsafeHtml(String) instead.

      Examples:

      paragraph.withInnerText("Hello World");
header.withInnerText("Welcome to JHF");
button.withInnerText("Click Me");

// User input is automatically safe:
paragraph.withInnerText(userInput);  // HTML is escaped automatically
      Parameters:
      text - the text content (will be automatically HTML-escaped)
      Returns:
      this HtmlTag instance for method chaining

    • withInnerText

      public HtmlTag withInnerText(SlotKey<String> slotKey)
      Sets a slot key for dynamic inner text content.
      Parameters:
      slotKey - the slot key to resolve at render time
      Returns:
      this HtmlTag instance for method chaining

    • withUnsafeHtml

      public HtmlTag withUnsafeHtml(String html)
      Sets inner HTML content that will be rendered WITHOUT HTML escaping.

      SECURITY WARNING: Only use this for content you completely trust (e.g., HTML from a trusted Markdown parser). NEVER use with user-provided content, as it can lead to XSS vulnerabilities.

      For user-provided content, use withInnerText(String) which automatically escapes HTML.

      Examples:

      // SAFE: Content from trusted Markdown parser
Div div = new Div()
    .withUnsafeHtml(markdownParser.parse(trustedMarkdown));

// DANGEROUS: User input - DO NOT DO THIS!
Div div = new Div()
    .withUnsafeHtml(userInput);  // XSS vulnerability!

// CORRECT for user input:
Div div = new Div()
    .withInnerText(userInput);  // Safe - automatically escaped
      Parameters:
      html - trusted HTML content that will NOT be escaped
      Returns:
      this HtmlTag instance for method chaining

    • addClass

      public HtmlTag addClass(String className)
      Adds a CSS class to this tag. Appends to existing classes rather than replacing them.
      Parameters:
      className - the CSS class to add
      Returns:
      this HtmlTag instance for method chaining

    • withClass

      public HtmlTag withClass(String className)
      Alias for addClass(String).
      Parameters:
      className - the CSS class to add
      Returns:
      this HtmlTag instance for method chaining

    • addStyle

      public HtmlTag addStyle(String property, String value)
      Adds or updates a CSS property in the style attribute. Merges with existing styles rather than replacing them.
      Parameters:
      property - the CSS property name (e.g., "width", "max-width")
      value - the CSS property value (e.g., "300px", "50%")
      Returns:
      this HtmlTag instance for method chaining

    • withWidth

      public HtmlTag withWidth(String width)
      Sets the width of this element using CSS.

      Accepts any valid CSS width value including:

      • Pixels: "300px", "500px"
      • Percentages: "50%", "100%"
      • Relative units: "20rem", "10em"
      • Viewport units: "80vw"
      • Auto: "auto"

      Examples:

      TextInput.create("username").withWidth("300px");
ContentModule.create().withWidth("50%");
Card.create().withWidth("20rem");
      Parameters:
      width - the CSS width value (e.g., "300px", "50%", "auto")
      Returns:
      this HtmlTag instance for method chaining
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - if width is not a valid CSS unit

    • withMaxWidth

      public HtmlTag withMaxWidth(String maxWidth)
      Sets the maximum width of this element using CSS.

      Useful for constraining elements while allowing them to shrink on smaller screens.

      Examples:

      FormModule.create().withMaxWidth("600px");  // Form won't exceed 600px
TextInput.create("email").withMaxWidth("400px");  // Input constrained to 400px
      Parameters:
      maxWidth - the CSS max-width value
      Returns:
      this HtmlTag instance for method chaining
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - if maxWidth is not a valid CSS unit

    • withMinWidth

      public HtmlTag withMinWidth(String minWidth)
      Sets the minimum width of this element using CSS.

      Prevents elements from becoming too narrow.

      Examples:

      Button.create("Submit").withMinWidth("120px");  // Button stays at least 120px
Select.create("category").withMinWidth("200px");  // Dropdown min 200px
      Parameters:
      minWidth - the CSS min-width value
      Returns:
      this HtmlTag instance for method chaining
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - if minWidth is not a valid CSS unit

    • getChildrenStream

      protected Stream<Component> getChildrenStream()
      Gets the stream of child components to be rendered.

      Subclasses can override this to provide a custom list of children, such as filtering empty components or enforcing a specific order.

      Returns:
      stream of components to render

    • render

      public String render(RenderContext context)
      Renders this tag and all its contents to an HTML string.

      The rendering process:

      1. Builds opening tag: <tagName
      2. Appends all attributes: class="x" id="y"
      3. Closes opening tag: > or /> for self-closing
      4. Appends inner text (if present)
      5. Recursively renders all children
      6. Appends closing tag: </tagName> (if not self-closing)

      Example output:

      <div class="container" id="main">
  Hello World
  <h1>Title</h1>
  <p>Content</p>
</div>
      Specified by:
      render in interface Component
      Parameters:
      context - the context containing values for dynamic slots
      Returns:
      complete HTML string representation of this tag and its contents
